item.title: Beginnings
item.content:encoded:
My dad at my age.

Ive never been someone who gets it on the first try.

I try and make up for that by being overly enthusiastic about almost all that I do. When I decided to explore the foundations and implications of Rome, I ended up performing better on my Latin tests. I was genuinely interested.

Now, to test that theoryif I can elevate, even romanticize, my life, could that improve my daily mindset?

I decided to take a gap year two weeks before Duke University wanted us to come to campus. This summer, while I was supposed to be in Greece working on a Classical Archaeology dig, I refused to stay idle. I signed up for EMT-B classes, and to say the least, studied harder than I ever have before; this time, what I read in the textbook felt more real than ever.

I deliberated quite a bit on whether I wanted to spend a whole year taking a break, as Ive never been one to slow down. But this isnt slowing down. Instead, I am refocusing my camera lens. I am grabbing a bag of popcorn only to grab the remote and hit play again.

And such, to document the pauses of this year, the empty spaces, the late night ambulance runs, and odd road trips, Ill be making my year quite transparent. This is a pausebut not an idle one.

item.title: AUGUST: CALIBRATION
item.content:encoded:
This month was the beginning of a prologue. Heres the concrete:

  • Registered and began classes at SMU to act as pre-matriculation credits for Duke

  • Drove to Austin, TX to build a chicken coop

  • Made money tutoring and doing Instacart to invest

  • Flew to visit friends in NJ before school starts

  • Finished EMT class final

  • Rejected from my favorite coffeehouse as an employee

  • Busted out my back right light cover on my cartoonish GMC Yukon

  • Decided Im going to buy two more chickens -- Silver Polish

  • Chickens started laying eggs

  • Found myself in my head more than I would like to admit

  • Written a measly three songs

  • Got my textbooks and one (1) piece of college gear

 

Places Ive been:

       Dallas, TX

       Austin, TX

       Hoboken, NJ

 Ive found myself explaining why Im taking this gap year every time I meet someone new. As most of my friends are starting to move in and begin their freshman year, Im feeling the pressure to be busy. I spend many nights after midnight applying to random jobs on Indeed. I got a call back from a drug-testing agency who turned me down because the job wasnt stimulating enough, and yet, the jobs I do want to work for say that Im not qualified enough. 

I am chugging along the process of becoming a certified EMT-B. My final was August 27th, and it went well! I spent the past two weeks studying in most spare minutes of my time. Sam reminding me that Id already explained how cool of a drug aspirin wasan anti-platelet aggregator?! I ended up panicking for the month before only to get far beyond the passing score.

I also met someone who works in the field of emergency medicine, and she was at the beginning of her registry. This isnt the most luxurious field of medicine with odd long nights, maggots in legs, and decapitated drivers. One of the hopes of this year is that I can figure out if medical school is the choice for me. A curveball that has hit me this year is that the process of being an EMT-B requires sitting in others inboxes, reminding them that this is the next barrier for you. The process accelerates and comes to quick halts before I can even find my footing. Next up is oral boards, which is basically an RPG medicine simulator, then clinicals. Usually, clinicals would last six weeks, but theyll be virtual and accelerated because of COVID. I am hoping that I will be nationally registered by the end of September.

One of the other things Im investigating is Paramedic school. My local community college offers a 6.5 month course, but its fairly intensive. The only pre-requisite is that I have my NREMTwhich is again time dependent.

I took a trip to Austin before I even finished packing. My OCD has created new turning points in my life, and I realized that Id been cooped up for far too long. After the three-hour drive, I spent a bunch of amazing time with my uncle, who helped me build our chicken coop. We wanted something for a few more chickensjust in case. I had collected a bunch of doodles of my ideas of mechanisms I thought would be cool for a coop to have, and we made it happen. Hell be coming down around Labor Day weekend to help us reassemble it.

It has been weird watching schools reopen. When I was committing to going this fall, I woke up every morning praying that all schools would operate as normal. Now that I dont have the same connection, Ive found myself to become much more worried about the well-being of the students. My mom and I think that Duke will last a month in person. Exeter starts again too, and I just hope students realize that education is not only in the classroom. It is real life experience. Thats what Im trying to believe.

I am hoping to go back to open-mic nights again. My favorite place has shut down their show, but a few others are still open. Music makes me feel incognito in DallasI can pretend to be a tortured folk singer with no other worries. 

Tutoring has been an unexpected joy. At first, I started it to turn my obsession with school into an employable skill, but its become something I look forward to every day. 

Ill be taking General Physics and Calculus at SMU. Im excited to have a bit of structure againI just want to make sure I dont automatically overload. 

Heres my ideal: going to class on Tuesdays and Thursdays, doing a few coffee shifts, and doing three 12-hour EMT shifts a week. Itll add up, Im sure. Ive gotten hired at Scooters Coffee, along with interviewing with Paper Source (which I hope will work out)!

Ive already learned so much about this self-navigated journey. I am learning to be more patient with myself and trust myselfjust because there is a test coming up does not mean I will fail it. Ive found ways to lean into my instinct, fail more, and send a whole lot of emails. I would try and be deep and reflective here, but it feels like thats for another time.

 

Until next.

Alex

item.title: SEPTEMBER: DOUBT
item.content:encoded:
This month felt much more real. Heres the concrete:

  • Got hired as a Server at Honor Bar, one of the Hillstone Restaurants

  • Continued to tutor 3-6 students per week, focusing on college counseling, English, and paper revision

  • Finished training at Scooters Coffeeofficially a Barista!

  • Hosted family from Austin to install the chicken coop

  • Got bees!

  • Failed a physics test

  • Got a flu shot

  • Passed my EMT oral boards; Clinicals pushed back

  • Began Anatomy and Physiology as preparation for Paramedic School at Dallas College

  • Test drove a Tesla, hated it

  • Bought a car!

  • Wrote (barely) four songs

  • Sang the entirety of Hamilton with friends until 2:00am

  • Hyper-analyzed why Im working at all

 

Places Ive been:

       Dallas, TX

This month has felt the same as Augustwhich is something I was worried about when I started this journey. I wanted each day to feel like a new, refreshing breath of air, but Ive found myself creating quite the opposite environment.

I think one of the things Ive learned already is that Im addicted to working. Not the quality of working or the satisfaction of working, but rather, I feel like being busy somehow translates to success. I have to admitI am nowhere near finding a balance for myself. One of my new fears is feeling more burnt out after this gap year than I felt after graduating.

It's been odd talking to friends who are now starting their freshman year of college, repeating the joy of our prep year. But we're in more of a similar situation than I expected: the troubles of finding friends, routine, and community. I can empathize with them with online learning as well. I'm taking three classes at SMU and one at Dallas College, all of which are online. I started the year on the right foot at SMU, forcing myself to go to the library on the days that I had classes to feel like a real student, despite using Google Maps to get there each time. That usually happens on Tuesdays, but on Thursdays, I feel drained, unmotivated, and lost.

Of course, failing my first physics test didn't help. I'm not talking about "darn, a 92, I could have done better." NoI'm talking a 46 out of 100. I weirdly expected this. Of course, not the grade, but I've avoided physics for so long because something about it always intimidated me. I'm not the greatest math student (which, however, doesn't mean I don't enjoy it), and I knew that conceptualizing pushing a boulder up a hill outside of a philosophical text would put me at the bottom.

It's been two weeks since I've found out about the test, and I've vaguely gone over it again, afraid to really sink my teeth in as a sign of failure. I mentioned this to my mom today, and she reminded me of my rationale to do this in the first place: I won't have to take it at Duke, and it will have no bearing on my GPA. And, not to mention, my professor drops the lowest test. Regardless, I'm feeling like a 46.

I love my coffee job, all for reasons that should be counteracted by the negatives. I'm paid $9 an hour, it's thirty minutes away, and it's an only-drive-thru location with approximately 50 square feet. I love the attention to detail when making drinks, the regulars who want half non-fat milk and half almond milk, the quick social interactions at the window before they're off to live their own bubbles. I love the people, most of whom are oddly studying psychology at Collin. It's the first time in a while I've I feel confident doing something alone, unprompted and unguided.

I also love driving down the tollway at 5:30 am. No one is there, yet the cars seem to give each other subtle nods: "Yeah, we're in this together. I get it, man."

One of the pitfalls of this month has been Clinicals. After passing my oral boards (which are basically glorified medical D&D games), I was cleared to start them. I scheduled them all back to back, pushing back my work schedule to get them out of the way so that I could find consistency again. All the paperwork on my end is completed, but the school I took EMT classes with which was supposed to set me up for a background test and drug test has fallen through. Two weeks of emailing, "did you get it?" followed by replies of "no, try it again?" But maybe the email tag buffer is a reminder that there is no rush to get on an ambulance. I have a year. Anyways, it's looking like the best-case scenario is mid-October, running 6 ambulance shifts with Acadian Ambulance and 2 hospital shifts at Medical City.

I like the idea of Paramedic school, but it's about time. Do I have time for 42-credit hours this year, over three semesters, squeezed between flex-mesters, summers, or any day that a professor will teach me? Regardless, I know my primary focus should be SMU since those are the courses that impact Duke. The only problem is that I love my medical classes so much more.

Honor Bar and I have a love-hate relationship. It's the opposite of Scooter'sit would make me far more money than I know how to spend, it's two minutes from my house, and would look much better on a resume. The only problem is that it's more stressful than my physics class. I arrive an hour before my shift for a test every day, whether it's over appetizers or their entire liquor collection. The problem is that I start seeing myself from others' shoes in that jobI wonder what I look like walking, wonder if my hair is "spec" enough. They love the word spec; context clues have led me to believe it's a bit above the standard, which, in turn, becomes the standard. I got a haircut for them, raided a Dillard's, but I still don't feel like I fit in. I'm definitely the youngest and most anxious person there, and they don't hold back in the name of politeness. It's about the guest, not you. I would say that I expected that part of the job, but I would be lying if I said that I expected this level of harshness. One minute, you're getting yelled at in Expo for drinking water, and the next, you walk to a guest's table with the brightest smile on your face (and it has to be wide enough for them to see you "smize," since masks have ruined most of our pleasantries). I'm almost done with training, and I hope that I'll feel like I can stand up a bit more for myself, maybe even stand up a bit straighter once this passes. As easy as it would be to quit, I want to stick through it past training, see if I like the weight of my wallet and emotional baggage, then decide from there. I'm hoping to start taking it as a critique on Alex the Mannequin rather than the Person.

I do think I use busy-ness as a coping mechanism. I had a wonderful conversation with a friend a few days ago who has requested to go by Anonymous Capybara. (Very funny.) The root of the question was: do depression and nihilism go directly hand-in-hand? Does the search for a "purpose" act as a pretense for creating meaning? I've never been one to believe that there is One True Purpose, and as a sucker for Kierkegaard, I believe each person's truth is subjective.

The problem is this: we see our future selves as completely different people. "Oh, my tomorrow self will have had an awakening and will want to write this paper, so I'll do it then." But it never works like that, and we always end up being disappointed. We are so, so, so bad at predicting the future. You apply to college, get into your dream school, celebrate for a few days, but after that, you're back to the muck of: why? You should be proud rationally, but something counteracts that, and you end up in the irrational pool regardless. So then, what is a purpose or goal that isn't short-term fulfillment? A perception that has benefiting qualities when you aren't sitting in an office, aren't clocked ineven will help you get out of bed after staring at the ceiling? I don't, or rather, we don't think that a purpose centered around your self-image or goals can do thatyou'll always, always be disappointed, always find a way to undercut your success and achievements. I brought up the example of people I consider more stable than two 18-year olds: parents. Sure, part of their purpose can be career or future based, but oftentimes their goals are oriented around their kids. Since they don't live in their kids' heads, they're finally able to experience the satisfaction of seeing that third-person entity succeed without the oozing neutrality that the first-person brings. Maybe that's why I want to be an EMT. The other problem?

These definitions of purpose are selfisheven the selfless ones; I'm rationalizing that your meaning of life should be centered around other people because it doesn't carry the same weight of doubt. (Although, if all purpose is selfish, maybe this is a little more selfless compared to the "be happy" truths. Who am I to say? It's subjective.)

Until next,

Alex

item.title: OCTOBER: STRANGERS
item.content:encoded:
This month was fast. Heres the concrete:

  • Stained the wood of the chicken coop

  • Added two more tutoring students

  • Got coffee with a few wonderful people

  • Aced my math midterm

  • Spilled an entire rack of silverware

  • Passed 200 song posts on my songwriting archive

  • Built a snowman at work out of styrofoam

  • Aced my anatomy final and finished the course

  • Dropped two fries on a table

  • Got a $100 tip





Ive been meeting strangers. Strangers who work jobs Id only seen the outsides ofthe siren of an ambulance, the humming of servers as I ate at Hillstone Restaurants, the grinding of the coffee machine as I waited in the drive-thru. I didnt think these stories were special enough to write about or explore truly; I went for the more obvious obscure. The gods and ancient heroes who had their history written already. I wrote this in December of 2019:

I think Im obsessed with the ancients because their stories have been told, and will continue to be told, for thousands of years. Theres something concrete about this legacy of the oldest myths and folklore; their worth and what they have amounted to has already been solidified. Theres no question that they are glorified through the manuscripts and Percy Jackson books. They got lucky.

Of course, they got lucky; its why myth and folklore remain the focus of so many of our modern-day literature. And for a long time, I was focused on how I could even be close to the myth of the ancientshow could I find a crevice in history to fit into when there was so much else to be remembered?

I have already forgotten most of this year. I spend most nights on the call with a particular friend, and at least once a night, he says, Did I tell you about? My response is always, I dont remember. Its not that Im not listening. I feel present in those moments; the stories and plots feel enveloping when the call continues. But when I hang up the phone, I move on. I close the door, lock it, and get onto the next scheduled activity. These myths are similarwe remember them when we want to, only when theres a significant figurative connection to our own lives. In truth, when we see ourselves or our story in theirs.

This is all to say that I have been focused a lot on the macro of this year. I continue to ask myself: what will be my answer when someone asks, What did you do with your gap year? Some took a ski trip, a retreat, or spent time with family. I want my answer to be that I have spent this year meeting strangers, just as I have met thousands through literature. But these strangers are real, empathetic, joyful, persevering people. There isnt the convenience of a Deus Machina, no heros journey to guide them to a gratifying ending. The rhetorical devices are what they make of them; the symbolism the same.

So how does working 40 hours a week through Honor Bar, coffee, and tutoring lead to that? Thats the issue Im contemplating. Not the quality of the work Im doing, but the quantity. I know that Im going to have to readjust once I start working as an EMT, but I have a while until then. I like the feeling of growing up, but I dont want to grow up too fast. I want to find a happy medium between clueless and jaded.

I start clinicals, officially, on November 11th. I will be in uniformhead to toe in vomit and blood resistant material, donned with more PPE than Ive ever worn. The nerves have subsided after months of waiting. Now, I want to begin. I want to meet more people who are crazy enough to put their own safety and wellbeing to the sidelines for the chance of saving someones story.

I also have to start thinking about a decision Im going to have to make in January. Paramedic school runs from January 25th to August 10th, every weekday 7:30-16:00. I know that I would love paramedic school, every single late night of studying cardiology. But its time.

The time that I dont have yet. Throughout that time, I have so many conflicts that would have to be shifted, contorted, or thrown out to commit. The nice thing is that the decision depends on how quickly I can get my NREMT, which could be anywhere from late November to the end of January. If it takes too long, I wont be able to take the curriculum regardless.

I am not the greatest server at Honor Barin fact, I am far from it. I average 3.5 mistakes per 7-hour shift. I have a spreadsheet that details each, with both the cause and solution listed. Its not that these things cannot be fixed, but it takes precious time. Rang in the Brownie Bites to the wrong table, but they havent been made yet? Thats fine, but spend the next six minutes fixing your mistake and writing a Comp while your Table 33 wonders if their server has forgotten about them.

I often feel like a small fish in a big pond. There was a bartender that was with Hillstone Restaurants for seven yearsseven years. I dont even know what growth over seven years looks like. Most people there have exit strategies, but some dont. This is life for some people. And thats not a bad thingits a good one: good pay, honest community, supportive management, and fascinating people-watching.

I will probably not be a server for the rest of my life. I, hopefully, will end up in academia, a hospital, or an archaeology site. However, there is a common threadI will always be working at least 40 hours a week. I love the feeling of shifting meetings into 30-minute crevices, getting home far too late or waking up far too early. I will always make mistakes, both big and small, regardless of what field I end up in. I will have to find a way to make the most of those six minutes.

If youre one of the strangers Ive met reading this, I hope you know that I no longer consider you a stranger. I am entirely on your side: I want to know your ups and downs, highs, and lows. That is what will make this year special.

Also, in re: Mechanics test, I took my second midterm for the class on October 22nd. I have yet to get the grade back, but I couldnt be less worried. I know I got higher than a 46, not because I knew every nuance of the material, but because I felt that each argument I made on paper was to the best of my ability. I love that bubble too. Students who are all mumbling about how hard their classes are, bumbling along from building to building, Zoom to Zoom. Im excited about that future, but now I notice moments where my old self would have fallen to the floor in despair.

This is small, which somehow makes it big. Not to mythologize my own life, but I left my wallet at home after a long shift before my Mechanics Lab. Problem: I need my SMU ID to enter the library for my Zoom class. So instead of crying in my car, wallowing in my own stupidity, I went into Expo and did something with my six minutes. I hopped into the Zoom call in a Tom Thumb parking lot and solved the hell out of that physics problem. No one asked questions about where I was or what mess I had gotten myself into this time; we were all worried about the maximum height a skier could reach after leaving the ice with a low friction coefficient.

I hope to see more things in scale next month. I hope to do more with my six minutes. Its not personal; its business.

Until next month,

Alex

item.title: NOVEMBER: REVERB?
item.content:encoded:
John* was just arrested for violating his probationby robbing a local store. His previous charge? Drug possession. 

John was young, dressed in clothes that I would wear, and sitting on the pavement next to the cop car.

Hi my name is Dave*, and Ill be the medic taking care of you today along with my student Alex. Whats going on?

John looked at me and said nothing.

It was my first call of that shift, around 9 in the morning. For the first thirty minutes of the call, all John did was mumble and look at me. It took me until the second glance to realize why he might be so absent.

I grabbed my pen light and looked at his pupilspinpoint. From my textbooks, that meant he was using opiates.

My medic preceptor stepped away to talk to the cops, and I kneeled down next to John, checking his vitals and overall condition.

John, have you taken any substances in the past 12 hours?

He looked at me for a minute before responding. I swear he didnt blink.

Morning, meth. Store, 3 Xanax. After, heroin.

The medic overheard him speaking and came over. He started looking for injection sites, but Johns arms were clean.

John, did you inject the heroin in your leg?

Another minute passed. Swallowed.

***

He said I wish I could start over again as we took him off of the floor and loaded him into the ambulance.

I rode with John for the twenty minute ambulance ride. He continued to try and talk, but he couldnt get a word out. Our assumption was that he swallowed the heroin to avoid another drug charge. While we didnt do anything in the ambulance since he wasnt critical, we knew what would happen to him when he got to the hospital. A whole lot of activated charcoal and, to say it nicely, emesis.

This month, I saw more real things than I have ever seen in my life. A suicide attempt, an alzheimers patient, an alcoholic; and somehow I saw myself or my peers in all of them. One of them, the alcoholic, showed my pictures of her addiction, and praised me throughout the ride for being on a good path, unlike [her]. 

That raises a new question: where exactly did they turn that I havent, or wont? What could they have done before that they didnt?

item.title: DECEMBER: PRESTIGE
item.content:encoded:
I finished the first semester better than I thought I would; it already puts me at a head start for Duke. But more than that, I feel like Im better fit to understand what Duke means for me. It feels like a stepping stone.

Another excerpt from a late night conversation: prestige is the expectation of success. It means that everyone expects you to be successful rather than the promise of success. I know that I can work hard at whatever Im aiming towards next; my ambition is not the fear. The fear is directionhow do I know that Im working towards the right future for myself? One that works for me instead of me working for it? I want the satisfying moments: helping someone back up, teaching someone a concept that theyve been trying to wrap their head around for weeks, having conversations that are mutually beneficial and curiosity inciting; the moments of a do-er.

I cant credit the word do-er; its a term used often by a close friend of mine. Someone who spends their time doing the real stuff and having a real impact rather than just a title or social prestige. I dont think I know anyone who I would consider a do-er, but I know a few people who come close. My mom, for example.

My mom has always said that each person has seven careers in their lifetime. This is an estimation, but Im pretty sure shes on career number 5. Five times, she looked at her stable position doing something she loved, and she said lets try something else. Thats a do-er mentality; seeing a challenge and choosing it over comfort.

The problem is that I enjoy comfort. Between soul crushing weeks and all-nighters, I take naps, play a few runthroughs of Hades, and watch YouTube. I spend five days of the week looking forward to the two that I have no commitments during; as if Im in elementary school waiting for Friday to come.

Its not that I dont enjoy my days at work; Im surrounded by smart, driven, and diligent people. People I love talking to, dreaming with, and hoping towards. But theres always relief in the last few hours as I finish up my last six-high of sticks. 

Thats what the future means for me. I hope, and this is a far-fetched dream hidden at the bottom of the sea, that I find a lifestyle that leads to me to look forward to the five days of the week. I like the structure of it, even the content, but the fact that its called work makes me feel like I have to be working towards someone else rather than myself. The 37 hours Im working dont directly quantitatively direct to personal growth. But the 100 hours do.

That mindset shift may never happen. For now, Ill clock in and clock out. 

I left my coffee job, and Ill hopefully start a new one soon. Financially, it didnt make sense to continue that particular job. More to come.


I take my NREMT on January 13th, two weeks from today. From there, it means a whole new schedule, a whole new perspective of leadership and burden. Not only for the company Im working for, but for the people Im caring for. 

Ill be working both on New Years and New Years Eve this year, but I still plan on a few resolutions. Heres a list:

  1. Do one thing every single day. Brew coffee, make my bed, write, read.

  2. Be ahead of classes instead of letting them be ahead of you. 

  3. Stop asking are you sure?

    1. And, on that note, stop apologizing after every sentence.

  4. Travel outside of the country; Greece?

  5. Spend more time learning.

  6. Release those albums.

No working out or eating healthy resolutions; I know thats out of my capability.

I have no clue who I want to be a year from now. I dont know if I want to go to medical school, pursue Classics, or spend my life traveling with a trowel; even scarier, something I dont even know yet. However, I know my trends. I know that I gravitate towards challenges and things I think are impossible. 

Heres to impossible, whatever that may mean.

Best,

Alex

item.title: JANUARY: WORK
item.content:encoded:
It's not that I don't know where I'm going. I know that I want to be a great like I've always thought. 

Every piece of silverware that goes through represents, to an uncertain extent, a guest. Usually, knives are more reliable, as they are used less often on appetizers. More often, they'll drop a fork on the floor. I roll, on average, around 287 sticks a day. A "stick" is a pair of fork and knife, wrapped into a cylinder of linen. According to a few days of timing myself with the wall clock, a "six-high," a stack of 6x6 sticks, takes around 8 minutes. So, 20 seconds a stick. I've divided it into 8 steps. 

1. Check the side of the linen. The inside of the linen must be facing toward you for it to be "spec." 2. Fold the square linen roughly in half in a triangle fashion, aiming for an inch distance from the topmost tip to the inner tip. Make sure the sides are parallel. If there is any discoloration in the linen, it's called "credit." This also includes things like tears, lint, loss of fabric, or thinning. 3. Grab your fork and knife, which you've already polished with water and distilled white vinegar. If there are any water stains or severe damage to the utensil, discard it. Then place your fork and knife in such an order: knife, with the edge facing the top of the linen, then fork on top. Make sure the fork is stable without extreme pressure. Make sure that your utensil pair lines up with the linen's top with an equal amount of the knife on either side. You can use the midpoint of the knife as a reference. 

4. Begin folding. Hold your right hand on the pair of utensils to keep them stable, and push the fork to the left as you pull the left side of the linen with slight pressure. As you drop the linen's left side onto the right, the utensils should remain on top of each other. Reposition your right hand to control the linen by moving it on top. 

5. Right side. Pull the right side of the utensils into the right side of the linen, securing its place. Once you've got something that looks like an envelope, we're onto 6. Roll up, ensuring the sides are parallel and pressure is kept. 7, readjust. Once you roll the stick into its cylinder, you're sure to have some overhang or loss of pressure. Rollback, then roll up, holding the top corner. 8, place in the same angle as the other sticks on the six-high; your six-high should look like a box rather than a lopsided tower. Sticks should be the same length and width. 

And that's most of my day. I'll roll out 1 or 2 six-highs, do all the other things people ask me to do, then wait for the next round of silver so I can go through the entire process again. It's very sisyphusesque: creating a product that has gone so many times around the restaurant's circular frame. I mean, we probably have something like 125 fork and knife pairs; 108 sticks should be on display for wipe-sets, basically bussing and setting the table, at all times. One by the Greeter's Stand, one by the linen cabinet, and one on the patio. The others are on the floor, and I wait for people to finish their meal, with a high enough restaurant volume for the hour, and roll.

It reminds me of Zorba the Greek; I like to get tired, to sweat, to hear my bones creak. I despise money, throw it away, squander it wherever and however it thoughtlessly enters my head to do. Im not a slave to lucre; lucre is a slave to me. On my honor, Im a slave to work.

My NREMT is rapidly approaching, and I feel like a fool. It's not that I don't know the material or even that I'm not capable of knowing the material; the problem is beginning. This test answers a lot of questions about the next six months. If I find a job as an EMT that conflicts with my Honor Bar schedule, is it worth it? Would I be killing my future by losing the extra 6 months of savings, or would I be missing out on the value that I was truly supposed to learn there? 

[Between these excerpts, I proceeded to fail my NREMT.]

Today, I brought our cedar plank roasted salmon to the CEO, whose worth has been evaluated at 4.5 billion dollars. My hands were a bit shaky, but: I spend my day surrounded by millionaires on the floor--investment bankers, medical professionals, consultants, drug dealers, basketball players--and I feel so far away from them. I think I can, and will, own at least a scale of that wealth in my lifetime, but I worry that I'm entirely alien to them. I feel like I've been watching my life in the third person for the past month, wondering.

I have yet to face the failure of my NREMT truly. I'm definitely a different person--I can tell because I'm not panicked. I'm not afraid that the future might outrun me; rather, we are walking side-by-side (perhaps, more accurately, the future is dragging me behind it with its short leash). I want to think that I am open and eager for change, but I think I am far more comfortable with comfort than I realized. I don't mind taking a day or two off, looking for ten-minute breaks throughout the day. The question becomes: what is it that I am doing during those brief suspensions of normal obligation?

I envision spaces in quite a different way than I occupy them. Archaeology is about the exploration of curiosity; working in a restaurant is executing regardless of the question. I wanted to be the explorer, never stopping at one question until it leads me to another, but when I'm working with my neck bent over a table, folding the same mundane sticks of silverware, I worry that I have lost the first impulse to ask, "why?" Maybe the money breaches some barrier that allows me to turn off my unbridled hope for the future, keeping me in place and position in the present.

I'm not a dreamer. I want to do and be things that I have not been or done yet, but that doesn't make me a dreamer. I have no idea of who or what that would look like; I have no idea what kind or what degree of success brings about the life I want. I think I value my life differently than others around me. While others might be dreamers of the most vivid degree, I worry more about how I will process thoughts than those thoughts.

Here's to worry; although I will do it regardless.

Best,

Alex

item.title: FEBRUARY: EXPOSITION
item.content:encoded:
Why do we do things that harm us? Why do we poison ourselves with alcohol, steep heights, terrifying beats that come out far past the sunset?

It's because we are Skinner's pigeons. If you leave us in the box enough, we will press the dot, and food shall come. What we often forget to realize is that if the pigeon had just waited patiently in the box for just long enough, the food would come regardless of our medial pecking. But to wait in the box staring at the wall is the patience of a lifetime.

When I was younger, I danced. Tap, ballet, jazz, whatever would keep me moving. I wouldn't say I liked it, but I had friends, a community, and most importantly, I had rituals there.

I danced for about three years. Every six weeks or so, we would have a concert. Twenty six-year-olds dressed to the nines (which mostly meant hair in a bun on the rare occasion). But for me, I loved the concerts more than anything else. Why?

After each one, my parents would bring flowers, seeping with a saturation of somewhere else. Flowers I could never find in a field, in a yard, by the creek. New flowers, illuminating strawberry roses. I would come home, wash off the spotlight and hairspray, and manicure the flowers for a home in our home. I knew they would die. So I would wait until the next concert to get them.

In the last year of dance, I told my mother how much I loved the flowers. She chuckled, looked down at her feet, and said, "We can get flowers whenever you would like, sweetie. They sell them around town."

I quit dance the week or so after. The dance, while exhilarating, was not where the flowers were coming from. The flowers came from the shop we drove past on the way to school; they were not new, not from a place I could never dream of visiting.

We are awful at patience. We set hundreds of goals that we fail to acknowledge. We poison ourselves with late nights, junk food, and patience.

All of this is to say that I am drunk on patience. I have minimal time; I ration out when to send one email when to wait for another. But I am patient. I am not rushing to the finish line; this is the part of the race that I find most exciting.

But we don't mind illness; we don't mind poor health; we don't mind compulsions if it means a lifetime of drunkenness.

I will wait. The problem becomes that I don't know how I will know the waiting is done; no toll of the bell or melted wax seal waiting for me on the "other side" in another world.

I have loved being an advocate for Kierkegaard's philosophy. While he would be considered a depressed teenager obsessed with individualized nihilism in the modern-day, I can identify with that quite strongly. Of all of his writings, here is a highlight: truth is subjective. This seems counterintuitive at first; what is truth BUT objective? Soren means that each person should have an interpretation of religion instead of a large systematic faith.

I want to add an addendum to "truth is subjective." I think that not only my truth but each truth is subjective. When I see a rock, and you see a rock, we will describe the rock differently. Same rock, different truths. This, of course, comes with more limitations. This means that if I assume my truth always differs from yours or any other's, I can no longer trust other sources of truth. But that leads to an arduous life; how can I expect to be the truth-seeker in all areas of my life?

Yesterday, when I was driving running errands, I kept looking back through my dashboard mirror and seeing faces. Face that I will probably never see again. I don't mind that, but the scarier idea is that I see them again but fail to recognize them.

I am reading a book lent to me by a coworker (who, if reading this, should know that they are a large part of my motivation to work each day) about neurological disorders.

One of the stories is about a man who cannot remember past 1942 or so. It's not that he remembers 1942 as 1942; he remembers it as the most recent present imaginable. He sees himself in the mirror, much older than he was in 1942, and accuses everyone around him of pulling a trick. Here is the point: without a present, without a past (that remains in the past), and without a future that recalls on the past and builds upon it, what remains?

The author asks if he is hurting.

"Are you miserable?"

"Can't say that I am."

"Do you enjoy life?"

"Can't say that I do."

I have so much ahead. But I am afraid of the future, and for the first time in a while, failure. I am afraid to retake my NREMT; I am afraid to book a trip to New York, I am afraid to find details about the archaeology trip this summer. I am scared because this pandemic has me feeling like 1942. My memories that feel real are all from January 2020 and earlier. That's not to say I haven't grown; however, I have no baseline to compare myself to my past. I look in the mirror, and I am surprised that a year has passed. It was not the worst year, all things considered.

I am making my own truth because there is no future to propel the past forward; there is a catalyst for change when recycled like scrapbook paper.

I can buy flowers from any grocery store, from roses to tulips, to my favorite orchids. But I have not ever bought flowers, for myself or someone else. Without the impending feeling of performance, there isn't splendor for the mundane of high buns and tights. The mundane becomes valuable when we are surrounded by the exceptional; when I am around some of the brightest in the world, I look forward to trudging through the snow to make a cup of tea on the fourth floor of my dorm to find only my mess. A pigeon a million worlds away, in a world I am now afraid of entering.

Confidence is not an emotion. Confidence is a filter, a presence mostly put on by those in authority or interviews; managers, executives--blatantly put, important people. My dad, especially, exudes unearthly confidence, and he can back it up with the utmost stubbornness. In this sense, I am jealous of him. My work is underlined by confidence: ensuring the guest thinks you know what you're doing in their best interest. The employees and managers who have been there the longest do it best. It's a smile the minute they approach the door; it's a genuine greeting. It's remembering someone who came into the restaurant a week ago and asking how their Shrimp Louis was.

Last night, due to the weather in Texas, the pipe above my bedroom broke. I've often seen the questions: what would you save in a fire. The first thing I went for? Paper. Letters, notes, books, and other miscellaneous parchments that I've been collecting my whole life. Friendships that I don't remember, camp friends writing letters about the world I never knew, old romantic relationships dwindling on paper, and letters from grandma. I'll be living in the guest room for the time being, and I've been mostly in hibernation since it's happened. The school has been canceled for the week, but work is still on.

I've moved many times within my own house. I lived in a bunk bed for most of my life; even when Emma, my older sister, outgrew it, I still kept both bunks. In the middle of Exeter, we finished a renovation on our house, and I moved to a new guest room. Now, I'm in (another) guest room. I feel, more than I ever have, which isn't saying much, that home feels like home. At Exeter, it felt like an interim, but after spending a year here, I know the house's routines, the familiar and the foreign. Am I a productive member of the house? Not quite. I live there as a college student who stays during vacation. I do the dishes, clean up after myself, but I rarely make the venture downstairs except to eat. I'm tired--perpetually tired. If I don't have anything on my agenda for that day, I will sleep. It never feels excessive; I feel refreshed after. This was the case at Exeter, too, but I had a much more full schedule.

I will be taking my NREMT the second week of March. I have decided, and I have committed myself to that timeline. If I pass, great; if not, more time to work. But I refuse to let this year pass without a certification under my belt.

We are not living alone. We are living with contractors, with insurance agents, with jackhammers and measuring tapes. We had a renovation a few years ago; I remember this feeling, but I don't remember feeling like such a stranger.

I got a poster today chronicling all of the weeks that I have lived and will live. I'm not even past the first fifth--I'm in the exposition of my novel. So, I raise the question: when does the rising action begin?

But we're not like novels; we are not like the dear films we love so much. As much as I would like to believe, we are not stories, and sometimes, there is nothing to be told, as much as I would like to speak. I wish there were more to tell. I wish that my days were not only jam-packed with meetings and events but with symbolism, motif, litotes, and hendiadys. When s, I halt the rest of the momentum, and I make it a story--a story out of what was seemingly coincidence.

I am obsessive out of necessity. I am obsessive because when the mundane dissipates, I grasp the novelty's fragments (in both senses of the word). There's no crime in such "romanticizing," but it means that I'm searching and working for something unpredictable and with unknown value. Sometimes I have picked motifs; I have picked words and ideas and stories that I want to be acquainted with or attached to, but those are not the stories I find myself telling to friends a few months later. I am looking for the out-of-control observation of phenomena that make me feel like a detective--that make me feel like I have found something no one else has found before. Which, in turn, provides the illusion of legacy, but it's far more selfish than that. It's freedom.

I'm flipping light switches like you do your first night at a hotel--some of them have dimmers, some don't seem to do anything at all, and for some reason, the switch to the bedroom light is in the bathroom. I noticed the correlation between when covid started and what I feel had been an impossible world. I forget so often that I'm living in a pandemic. But I forgot that being a part of history means that you're the one who has to read about the last time we have faced such a burden, but in vain--we are growing so far out of our natural scale that we could never keep up if we tried. That's how we evolve; it might not seem as natural as so-called natural selection, but I think it's better to think of it as a practice. Skills that we practice often get better, features and tools and structures in society that aren't practiced, such as a coin, have obvious incentive to rid the scene and find a way to be within our Anthropocene scope of practice.

With that, heres a toast to repetition.

Best,

Alex

item.title: MARCH: PROPRIOCEPTION
item.content:encoded:
For the larger part of my life before boarding school, I have lived on a busy neighborhood street, named after a bird. (I shall avoid the name of the street for privacy reasons.)

This street is near the middle school I went to; so close that I could in fact walk home. When I was in my later middle school years, I usually did. It was a routine that I usually hated: walking home in the 90 degree heat for even a few blocks was pitiful. I never wore short sleevesI didnt feel like a real person at that stage of my life. So I sweat the whole way.

That wasnt the only problem with walking home. I was terrible at actually going home. Sometimes we would walk to 7-11, stop by others places, and get into all sorts of trouble. Its easy to say, looking back, that I was so unbearably lost that I clung onto the identity around me. I didnt have the greatest taste in friends. 

When I walk down that street now, I feel like the world is shorter. I haven't grown that much since I was living there, but I still feel like it was a million worlds away. I now work on that streetjust a few blocks away.

***

Ive picked up more shifts at Honor Bar; this week, Im working 43 hours. That wont be every week, but itll be more than my routine was accustomed to. Ill be able to do it without much life interruption, but it means that the projects I was waiting to do when I was less busy are now happening at the same time.

I am recording at least 3 songs from my next album on March 10th. My writing process this year has been very erratic for songsmost of the time I pick up my guitar and write a full song from start to finish; other times I can only come up with a catchy chorus without any substance. I want to be a musician for the rest of my lifein fact, I dont think I could stop if I tried. But my musical creative path is becoming jumbled. I was supposed to release an album in June at the end my senior year, but I pushed it off since I was putting all of my time and energy into Metamorphoses: Myth into Songs. 

But these songs have aged on me. While no one else has heard them, Ive played them to myself a thousand times. My favorite song is always my newest, implying that the reason I like it is because its newer and different. I was proud of those songs six months ago, but I am quite dreading practicing them.

It makes me feel like Im in 1942 all over again. Except with bigger goals and broader deadlines, which I set and can change.

I have been chugging through this semester, barely. Physics is a struggle as always, but Im trying to be proactive about support and strategies. 

Its been a few weeks now, and there are still people roaming our halls fixing holes and ceilings. The difference is that now my schedule requires me to be up earlytheres no hiding in bed anymore. They moved the fans out, finally.

For a week, no one could hear each other. Unless you were screaming, you had to be a maximum of one foot away from each other, directly yelling towards their face. 

I got a heat blister yesterday from holding an absurdly hot plate. I dont mind hot plates or burning glass anymore. I see it as more of a challenge. Ive built up enough calluses from this job and playing guitar to make it through about 15 seconds before I start to really feel pain. Of course, I could wait until everything has cooled down, but by that point Ill have twenty other things to do.

I find that Im much more tolerant to pain than I have been in the past. When I was younger, I would cry if I got a papercut; I dont know if Im better at ignoring them because Ive had hundreds, or if I dont mind what pain the papercut could possibly cause.

Wittgenstein defined proprioception as a sense of ourselves; to feel our bodies as our own, A classic example of this is to be able to distinguish whether youre standing on cement as opposed to grass.

I dont know where Im standing. I dont know what Im feeling, let alone what surface Im standing on. If I knew what I was walking on, maybe I would know where I am. Or where Im going.

I have a lot of fears that remain unresolved. I have a small sense of hope for this summer; the President claims all adults will be vaccinated by the end of May.

So does this end then? Texas just lifted its mask mandatea bit recklessly,, I might addand is now allowing 100% capacity. Does that mean my amnesia is over? Does this mean the present will be present, rather than an option that the circumstances lead me to?

This is not the gap year I anticipated. I have stayed busy, finding new passions and habits, all while living life around other people. But I think that this has been the best choice for meregardless of obstacle. 

Ive been saving every dollar Ive made this year to invest. This is good for my future, but it provides something else: a backup plan. 

Very few of my passions happen to be tied to lucrative careers. Most include living on a campus and working with a small team of people who are all curious and excited about something.

Everyone is trying to get out. My question isnt why they want to get outthat becomes evident after 6 months of working there. But where to?

Do the servers who want to do real estate, the ones who want to go to medical school, to financedo they see that as an ending? As a destination?

If anything, I see my possible futures as problems rather than conclusions. If I choose to educate, that means at least a Masters doing something new and unique in a field that is older than I can imagine. If I choose medicine, theres no way that Im passing the MCAT. If I choose archaeology, Ill spend around 6 years working on other digs before I even have entry level supervisor experience. Of course, if Greece cant happen this year, Ill have to wait until at least my sophomore year until my next dig, at which point I might change my mind entirely. I am finding myself anxious about planning because I dont know who Im planning for.

Have I changed that much over this year? Or do I think that Ive changed because I need to justify the delay in my traditional education? Will this all remain in the fall? Will our lives feel like they're on hold until they hang up before we get a chance to start again? 

This year has been scratched from the record for many. But a year has never felt so shortI remember the day I was told I would not be graduating on campus, the day I said farewell to the few whom I had much more to say to, the day I made my last efforts to reach out to those who I wish I knew. I think Im still trying to do that now.

I dont regret anything about this year. I have adapted the time management skills of Exeter into the real, raunchy, world. But how much do I need to know about that world? Is it worth my time being adaptable if I have no need to adapt in the future?

I have mostly written questions up to this point; questions that I have yet to answer. Maybe I shouldnt answer themthat must be part of the fun, then.

I have been building up the courage to ask for a raise at work. Ive recited to myself why this makes sensein fact, it makes plainly obvious sense. But I expect to walk into the office and be fired instead of given a raise. I always assume everyone above meteachers, managers, coworkersis not on my side. 

My mom reminded me of this recently. She has always been on my teameven when I disagreed with her strategies. I dont think Im always on my team, however. 

I dont often feel anger. I usually resort to fear, sadness, or disappointment before anger. But I must admit, I am angry that it has been a year of being a part of history. I am looking on the horizon, waiting for our roaring twenties'' after the 1918 pandemic, but Im so used to being let down that I cant make plans for whenever normal returns to our world. I want to travelto Arkansas, to New York, to Exeter, to Italy, and most of all, to Greece. More than ever, I miss not knowing when travellingwalking into a restaurant and not knowing what youre going to order, driving streets that youve never driven before, meeting people you would never meet in your bubble of a neighborhood, or on your hometown street named after a bird.

I think I am angry because I dont know what I lost. When its a bad grade, an argument with someone, or a missed opportunity, I know what I lost. I have no inkling of what this year would have been like if it just happened normally; and it might have been worse.

I panic when I lose my sense of choice. I can deal with uncertaintyas long as I have agency within the unpredictable. When that fails, I hibernate. Why be out taking risks in the middle of a flood?

I finished my 8th album todaya feat that sounds far more impressive on a resume than in reality. I love writing music; more than writing music, I love performing music. One of the things I miss the most is a coffee shop I used to perform at weekly in Summer 19. I would test song ideas, revise on the fly, duet with 40-something strangers. 

Ive been to many open-mic nights. But I have met very few professional singer-songwriters. Theyre all waiting to make it before they ditch their barista job; waiting on American Idol to give them a golden ticket; I dont think that bargain is worth it for me.

Would I be a full-time musician if I could? Sure. Could I? No. I dont write music proactivelyits a coping mechanism, its a source of comfortI would say that its analogous to rewatching the 6th season of a show youve seen so many times. Its home, in an odd way.

Ive never been a phenomenal songwriter, partly due to the guise of Im not doing this for a career. But do I not have a career? As of March 29th, I will have published 77 songs over my lifetime. Most were recorded in my closet with a microphone from Amazon, but this is my life history through music.

I never listen to my old music, and I often cringe when others put on the oldest tracks. In fact, I dont listen to my music in front of anyone but my parents, who always have something to say. Recently, my dad noted that, You dont have a chorus.

Of course, as someone who has far more familiarity with the word chorus than my father does, I tried to oppose it. I showed him the repetition in the song, the three repeated stanzas.

But I wouldnt ever hear this on the radio. Thats not a bad thing. Its poetry, not a song.

My usual reply is that I dont care about ever being on the radio, in re: not taking this seriously. But I agreed with him. I dont think I would ever hear this on the radio, and this raises a potent question.

If, within the field of music, I have somehow made a niche (or I have just been making bad music) that is even more unlikely to result in a lucrative career, what does that say about this mentality towards other hobbies or aspirations of mine? Does writing music about Classics make it simply poetry, or does its uniqueness make it a lucrative asset? Is my writing useless without scale?

I am a selfish personIve always admitted that. And while I know there are some people who do add these songs to playlists, I am far more concerned about the real business of lifelegacy.

There are times that I look back on a release from a year ago and regret it. If only the guitar had been a bit quieter, if only I had added or removed some odd harmony, maybe then it would be better.

But Im in this for the marathon. Im in this for recordkeeping. Its another obsessioneverything is chronicled in those songs. Ive journalled most of my life, but there are gaps spanning years. But I couldnt ever put down songwriting if I tried.

Of course, as the person living from my perspective, its quite easy to think that this is a one man act. (In connection to EXPOSITION.) Songs capture more than words donot only am I recording what I want to say, but how I want to say itwith a major or minor chord, with a juxtaposing melody, with a whaling cry. There are many songs of mine that overlap, both in chords and key, but also in topic. From love, heartbreak, fear, hope, or desperationbut never from anger. That feeling has yet to be chronicled in this so-called encompassing record.

So, should I write an angry song? To whom? And, perhaps more importantly, for whom? Who exactly is it that I am so angry at?

No one. I am angry at no one; but I am furious at the lack of entropy. I am furious at the lack of momentum. I am furious at the history books, at the billions of human bodies that are so susceptible to something so disruptive. Its easy to forget that were just like all other beingswe have endings. We have finales, denouement, but no rising action or climax. 

I want to be a force to be reckoned with. Do I eliminate that chance by refusing to change to the more potent product? Is this lack of ambition, or creatively driven stubbornness?

If Im going to be writing poetry, Im going to make sure it feels damn like poetryevery word will have a purpose, every story will have a tension.

I am a Nationally Ceritified EMT. Part of this is scarylooking around to make sure that no one made a mistake. Now its in my handsthe health and wellbeing of everyone who calls 911.

Ive only called EMS a few times in my life, but I remember each and every instance vividly. Its odd to think that what is a once in a lifetime experience for some will the the daily routine for mewhich comes twofold. Ill be able to help people when they hit their lowest, but Ill also be there when there isnt anything I can do. Its on me nownot as a student, not as a scribe, but as a first responder. I didnt even know what a first responder was until COVID allowed news articles to put them in each and every headline last year.  

There are so many in-betweens ahead. Ive been thinking about memory permanencethe fact that I vividly remember my lunch from today, but if you asked me about lunch a month ago, I would be pulling at straws. Theres a reason for thisits important for me to know what I had for lunch today and when, which will allow for a proper dinner and nutrition. But that scale only lasts around 24 hoursthe question remains: what sticks?

Pain sticks. Love sticks. Hope sticks. Desire sticks. I couldnt tell you what I had for lunch in 2015, but I can tell you who I wanted to be, who I wanted to love, and who I was so dreadfully furious at. 

I dont remember when, but we had an assignment when I was in middle school to write a letter to our future selves. These letters work best, of course, when we dont remember what we wrote all those years ago. But in this and all analogous assignments, I vaguely remember what I said, what I thought I would need to hear five years down the line. Usually I wrote about needing to make 10 albums before I could enter into my Taylor Swift era. Perhaps a bit more forecasting and accurate predictions could have been weighed in the hands of my 10 year old self, but I dont blame the past at all. (I also could not have predicted Taylor Swifts future, let alone my own.)

The truth is we cant predict what will stick. As a parent, you dont know if your kid is even going to remember their terrible 4th birthday with a black eye, but I do. Ask me about birthdays 5 through 12? No idea.

What we remember and what we have done comprise our identity. Memories teach us lessons school never got around to, and we act accordingly. So am I only my 4th birthday, and not my 5th through 12th?

No, because I have that 24 hour period. There are crushes I dont remember, stuffed animals that I couldnt tell you the name of. But it mattered then. I weighed it into my character during those moments, which is part of the reason that I am older, and most of the reason that I am not the same person that I was when I was younger. We shiftpartially because of the new experiences around us, but also because of the old experiences that we end up keeping. All I can truly remember is right now.

So I will continue to walk this road named after a birdpartially out of necessity, but mostly out of bittersweet nostalgia for something that I will never remember with as much clarity as I once did.

Until next,

Alex

item.title: APRIL: MIMICRY
item.content:encoded:
We are living in the temporary. I am living with people who do not imagine this as an essential part of their life. Their work is the subtext, and Im too far in the details to be seen in this montage scene. 

I have yet to keep a plant alive longer than a few weeks. I remember to water it for the first few days. Still, as I realize that the rest of my life remains largely the same, I know that I do not have the time or the emotional energy to care for a living thing, be it a significant other or a monstera. There is nothing quite as embarrassing as watching your two-week-old plant die on the windowsill.

We are not meant to be immortal. We would be far worse people if we were. And such as we shouldnt be immortal, the only worse sin would be to be immobileunmoving and unchanging, teasing the fleeting time.

Ill be leaving Honor Bar soon. I never thought a job would feel like an odd family. Im not close to everyone there, but I hope to maintain many friendships with people remaining in Dallas.

Does our awareness of time fleeting make it harder or easier? Does knowing things will pass make us wait until they do or dread the day they do? I usually try to lean on the optimistic side, but dread is far easier than patiently waiting. I dread the time passing because I dread change. I  trust myself to adapt to such change, but it means more decisions, agency, and responsibility to do the right thing with my life. Am I doing that now?

I am under, as we say in the service industry, in many areas of my life.

Chess has taken up many hours of my life. I have been playing every night when I get home from work and first thing in the morning. Im no goodindeed, if I were good at the game, I would most definitely brag about itbut I think I keep playing because every single game is different. Unlike other games Ive played, there is something below the surface with chess. I can tell when Im playing against a person or a computer. I can tell what moves are fundamentals of the game or a personalistic choice. I can look a little ahead into the future, giving me a pseudo-sense of time travel. If a game can give me that, Ill play as much of it as I can. 

I have always been pretty aware of the fact that people come in and out of my life. It has been, however, far more evident recently than in the past. From Exeter, I keep in touch with those close or even tangent to; there was a shared drive towards creativity. But from Honor Bar, each server and staff member is on their path in a wide variety of directions, ranging widely in age and chances of success. 

I am trying not to panic. That usually doesnt develop quite well, as trying not to panic leads to panic when I fail. My finals are coming up, I had my last day of work, and the future looks quite murky. I am afraid to fully commit because it means defending an end that I am not sure I am prepared or cut out for. 

I am not sure why I fear becoming an adult; I am constantly yearning for the future while feeling nostalgic for my past. Its not that Im not able to live in the present, but I dont see the same appeal in the now as I do in the was and will be. It doesnt become storytelling until its a part of the timeline or a prediction later on in the plot. The grass is greener on the other side until it seems that when you finally arrive, its not quite the green you hoped it would be.

It is all, whether we like it or not, in our control. Sometimes it is easier to suspend itto believe that you have left it up to the Universes weavers to decidebut you are the one who feels regret. Who feels doubtful. Who could or would have said just one more word if only you believed it was in your hands. I have wavered on this topic; control, a manageable amount, eases much of my anxiety, but an overwhelming amount feels like machinery, and a lack of it entirely leaves me aimless and without fear of the future. That fear is what waters the grass, by the way.

I went to the Texas Fair Park Butterfly Gardens with a good friend of mine, and the actual site was beautiful. I dont think much about insects anymore, which comes hand in hand with tempting agoraphobia, but seeing them without the world's business was quite a spectacle. They are magnificent creatures: polymorphic and masters of mimicry, capable of traveling greater distances than I have seen, and aposematism. Aposematism is the mastery of advertising fraudto ward off enemies by making them believe you are poisonous. I feel proficient in mimicry, but only because I leave myself open, leaving no illusion of danger. Thats not to say I have any need for aposematism, but sometimes I wish I could ward everyone off with just a glance, without any need for explanation. (Which, in retrospect, feels more aligned with the insects ability to camouflage.)

While we were in the main butterfly greenhouse, an older man sat in a chair near the entrance with a volunteer nametag. He said nothing as we entered the conservatory, but as we slowly made our way to the end, he chirped up. 

Did you see the quail? A few moments of looking at the ground instead of the trees below us followed his question.

Sure enough, there was a quail quite happy at the bottom of the bush, making eye contact with him. My friend and I proceeded to laugh and wave at the bird, who lacks all ability to understand what a wave, let alone a greeting, could mean from a human. It stayed put with its head perched. 

The man, whose name I would kill to remember, showed us some aspects of the butterfly house we had missed and demonstrated his vast knowledge of the site after ten years of volunteering there. After our few minutes of conversation had died down, he whistled.

Wihh zel! We both made eye contact with him in wonder.

Wihh...zel! The bird was not late to reply. 

Wihh...zel! The man chuckled to himself, but we stayed focused. A one-time reply can happen by all means of coincidence. So we witness many trials to ensure the precision of our data.

Wihh...zel! With the loveliest sudden sentence, the bird called back, replying back and forth ten times in succession.

There is not much more to say about the man and this quail. Im sure they continued talking far after we headed out the sliding doors. I wonder how many birds he has spoken to over his ten years and how many times they reply in a way he can understand. How many times he has worried about them calling back.

You may call it mimicry, but I see no reason to believe that this man would mimic for ten years. I worry about being different people in different parts of my lifeone of the places that I felt that the most was at Honor Bar. I felt like I was making calls, not because I trusted what they meant or believed they worked, but because I adapted to the people around me. So I am left with the question: is it mimicry if you pretend full-time? Is it mimicry if you act transparently? If you start to believe the illusion?

The future, as usual, is terrifying. But I hope I can find the call of a quail, to remind me just how much we are pretending. 


Until next,

Alex

item.title: MAY: CERTAINTY
item.content:encoded:
I am more worried about college now than I was last year because Ive been out of an immersive academic environment for a year. I sometimes mistake that as a weakness, but the whole point of this year was to lean out of the burnout stage of my life; to do what I want to do because I have a curious drive to do so, rather than some other numerical or quantitative motive.

There are only a few months left until Im in the belly of the beastthat time will pass far faster than I think it will. 

A few of my friends, not just coworkers, are quickly fading out of my life due to new chapters. After seeing so many come and go, I dont expect to keep in touch; instead, I hope that if we one day end up in the same 20-mile radius, I might go out of my way to reconnect. 

I feel tremendous guilt when I rest, and as I do all things, when I do rest, I rest in excess. This habit isnt necessarily a bad thing when I dont have too much on my plate, but it also means that I withdraw myself from the statement if only I had the time. The time will always come; the more significant question becomes how to use and prioritize this time. Im not sure if its due to laziness or a lack of inspiration, but Ive been moving quite slowly on all of my projects.

I am tired of analyzing the uncertain. It feels repetitive, Sysiphian, and somehow, that is not enough reason for me to stop. I know there is a strong likelihood that I might learn something along the way, but there must be a better way to be a person by learning through mindset and principles rather than hoping you make mistakes that teach you lessons you didnt know you were supposed to learn. Suppose instead I believe or abide by a declaration of curiosity and exploration. In that case, I am left with the same cycle of analyzing what feels most pressing--the uncertain, predictably back in the very place it began. That is what makes it so intriguing to me--it is genuinely unavoidable. 

So what is inevitable? You could go back to Descartes, who would reply that the only certain thing is whomever, or rather, whatever can doubt its existence. Maybe Im addicted to proving that I am certain.

But the I is notably not included in interpretations of Descartes certainty clause. The thinking thing is certain, but whether you (the person you would scowl at in a true mirror) are the one in control of that thinking thing; whether you are a figment of imagination deceiving the thinking thing is uncertain.

So then I leave my good faith invested in my thinking thing. Its not necessarily my brain, and calling it a spirit would be a stretch, but somehow, I can control it or perceive it. Perceiving it is a far scarier idea--that would mean that even the process of doubting can be deceiving to I...

For the sake of reasonable certainty, I usually hope that I am in control of my thinking thing. But sometimes I lose it: when Im stressed about something retroactively mediocre, when I lose something I didnt even think I had, and when I leave doors without tapping the other side twice. Rituals and spirals, in my experience, go hand in hand. There is nothing scarier than watching yourself perform a script out of pure skepticism.

So when I am faced with uncertainty, which often leads to anxiety, I rely on my thinking thing. But my thinking thing is also not entirely playing by my rules--sometimes it wanders, repeats, and scrutinizes the intonation of a text. 

Its not a civil war, and overall I think our relationship works. But it always comes back: the fact that the mechanism that I rely on for certainty is certain, but in a way that I cannot control, leaves me feeling agentless, primitive, passive, and prey. Prey of some machine far above me, and at this point, weve taken the train back to existentialism.

Most traditional western metaphysical philosophy ended after Kant (he must have had a few pretty important things to say), and weve abandoned most of the big questions over a few thousand years. Kant leaves us behind, telling us that we shouldnt worry about what is above or beyond us since we cannot perceive that world with clarity.

But an essential pillar of Descartes is that you can only be sure that the thinking thing exists when you are in the process of doubting your existence. Ironically, I feel the least is certain when the present doesnt feel real enough, especially when all I can seem to focus on is certainty.

And even if, by some miracle, the thinking thing (while doubting) is the only certain thing, I dont think it means that its the only thing that matters. There is much importance in the uncertainregardless of daunting it may seem. Out of control and reckless prophecies lie in the skeptical. I control it to a certain extent, but theres a veil of ignorance to make the game fair and make sure that I'm not too self-aware.

As I face the future, I hope to evaluate uncertain questions rather than evaluate what is and isnt certain. I hope to take a page from Kant and instead of asking why? I hope to ask, so what? 

I dont think there is any solution to fear. The natural way to alleviate it is to comfort the worry: somehow prove that there is no rational reason for fear, but Im tired of coming up with logical explanations for irrational emotions. This question remains at the top of my mind, and the short story that I have been working on this year (a long short story) aims to confront that question. 

How is the very thing we are afraid of, which tends to be death, is resistant to any more rationalization about itself? The characters are being chased by something that appears to be life-threatening, and even as they learn more and more about it, they dont feel any more relieved. Death itself could wave its hands and explain that its here, but the fear of death remains prominent regardless. That is the duality of rationalization and emotionwe believe that describing feeling will subside it, but despite rationalization, emotion pursues since it is inherently irrational. We explain that we are sad because the world seems to be ending, but the causation doesnt imply a cure. So in the meantime, we come up with smaller and smaller fragments of meaning, which aim to distract us. 

I cant decide if its better to be distracted or to confront the truth. I dont know if thats my decision. In the meantime, I will let it happen around me.

I have a very odd songwriting process. About once every three days, Ill get a melody or song lyrics running through my head, after which I will promptly record an improvised song based on the seed. Sometimes the improv will be awful, and I commit to dropping the idea entirely; sometimes its what I imagined, and I only have to change a few words; but most often, it is a stanza or two of work that I am proud of, and the rest is repetitive jumble (as improv is expected to be when done repetitively). I learned this technique through summers in creative writing programs. I had one teacher who told us to write a six-page paper on a topic, and they asked us to scrap everything except the last sentence and start from there. 

Its much easier for me to make a first draft than for me to make revisions. Revisions imply that something has been somewhat polished, and its hard for me to accept when something is ready or if it should be scrapped entirely. It goes back to the idea that it doesnt feel like a failure if you never try your hardest. The problem with that strategy is that I have no idea what my best is, and I'm not sure how to force myself to get there. 

In summary: certainty doesnt alleviate anxiety, and there isnt much that does in a long-term manner besides resolution. Im on the edge of a cliff right now, and Im hesitating to jump out of fear, but that fear may permeate over years and years--so why not jump now? And how do I materialize that jump to make sure that it means more than a first draft?


Much is uncertain, and much is to be feared. I dont expect that to change anytime soon. 

Until next,

Alex
