item.title: JANUARY: ACCOUNTABILITY
item.content:encoded:
After a ski trip that I was mildly unprepared for and a winter break of rest, Im eager to start the new year after lots of hot chocolate and board games. Im weary, however, as my stamina tends to diminish exponentially after the first six weeks of school. As such, I hope to find ways to be sustainable and consistent in my habits this year.

Once again, I search for New Years Resolutions, from getting fit to reading more, all things I always tell myself Ill do. However, Im hoping this year will be different, as Im adopting a system called the 12-week year that aims to hold me more accountable to myself and make the change as needed.

I also try to shake the guilt of falling off schedule this year. Far too often, I sleep in after a long night of working, and instead of celebrating what I accomplished, I seem to pinch myself for a morning wasted. 

Last year, my word was consistency. This year, its accountability. Now that I have systems to stay on track and keep up with the buffer work, how can I be proactive in holding myself accountable for my work, relationships, and long-term personal and career goals? 

It all goes to say that many things are left to a roll of the dice, a chance that we take on ourselves. So Im just hoping I might get lucky if I take that chance every day.

I love my classes starting the semester, from reading Euripides Medea in Greek to Computer Architecture. It will be a demanding course load with many small and large-scale deadlines, but I hope to find ways to give myself as much buffer as possible. Especially as I start considering future thesis topic ideas, I have been using my Notion religiously to store the tiny seeds that I come up with that might one day turn into a years project. My biggest fear is that I wont be original in my findings, and especially in a field such as classics, its hard to be the first to say something. So the other pivot is instead of approaching it as having to carry the burden of coming up with something original, which is quite rare and not necessarily an indicator of quality, instead focus on coming up with a new way of saying something that has been noted for many hundreds of years. To be determined.

The biggest goal Im hoping to reach is to find an internship in computer science, specifically within software engineering. However, after 93 applications, Ive only heard half-hearted rejections as I find myself in an internship pool with far more respectable applicants. Its difficult to shake the feeling of imposter syndrome as I scramble together miscellaneous projects that Ive started and hoped to finish to prove to an online application that I am somehow qualified.

The secret is that you dont have to be qualified, but Im tired of trying to prove myself over a screen. The process makes me anxious to find a job upon graduation. No matter what, the option to return to digging always remains open, like an alluring light at the end of the tunnel. I am heartbroken at the reality: to make a change in a field like archaeology, not only does it take a tremendous amount of additional schooling, but I want to apply new software and technology to an area without funding and the broad challenge scale. I want my job title to be one that no one has done yet.

The pull back and forth between archaeology and computer science, especially as I approach over a hundred software internship applications and have yet to be successful. It almost feels impossible to convince someone over a screen that Im a qualified and eager student. Still, I aim to stay hopeful, especially as more applications come out in the spring.

So how do I train or educate myself to be someone I dont know? That, again, is another door that remains far too open at twenty years old.

So without further ado, I have an outline of what the next few years look like for me. Of course, this is just a plan, and plans are meant to change, but heres the blueprint, at least:

Long Term Vision to be accomplished in the next five years:

  • Spend a substantial amount of time in Italy. Why? Because I find myself learning at a far faster pace when I am in a culture of exploration.

  • Become entirely financially independent and develop a system to ensure personal financial success. This will help with shaking the sense of panic.

  • Grow intellectual pursuits and creations through reading, writing, and singing. I want to find a sustainable way to keep creativity in my life throughout my twenties and hopefully further. 

As I continue to share my goals, remember that they are meant to stack upon each other.

  • Learn Italian proficiently. I want to find ways to make language acquisition second nature through daily grammar and vocabulary reviews and conversations with my Italian friends at least once a week.

  • Build a habit of reading for both creative and professional endeavors. For example, if I plan on continuing to create, I want to explore new content almost constantly, from books to podcasts to video essays.

  • Develop a passive income. This is tied to my financial independence. In the past, Ive found ways to do freelance work, from editing, writing, revising, and tutoring, but I want to build a small branch of passive income projects that I can watch steadily grow and improve throughout its distribution.

  • Implement a sustainable long-term financial system. I want to build a timeline with a number in mind after my first internship and block out how much money or percentage of my income I want to keep invested, saved, and budgeted.

  • Get a fulfilling career in Computer Science. I love this fieldI love the creativity that computers offer, and I want to work for a curious, collaborative, and motivated company.

  • Get fit. Especially as I grow into my early twenties, I want to build good habits of taking care of my body. The biggest reward of this goal is the impact that working out has on my sleepI end up falling asleep far faster and sleeping at a far higher quality.

  • Create compelling discography. I want to continue making music in a sustainable fashion that operates as a creative outlet.

So that brings us to today. Ive got a lot on my plate, but its because I believe the career-entry phase of my life will prove critical. Think of jobs like a ladder: if I can start at a higher rank, Ill be able to continually chase the most challenging opportunities and open as many doors as possible.

Ive also implemented smaller goals, such as not looking at my phone as often, especially when walking. In the past, I used the time between classes to drill flashcards or clear out my inbox, but I want to focus on being more present, especially in these passing moments.

How do we set goals without kicking ourselves for each day that seems to pass by without success? How do I one day decide that Im going to take my life into my own hands, with each minute more precious than the last?

It all starts with a mindset. A mindset that every step I take in the right direction is one less step Ill have to take later on. So even if a few nights are long and mornings are shorter than expected, I still have a few things to knock off a to-do list that bring me closer to my goals.

 So for the first 13 weeks of the year, Ill be targeting my focus on a few goals:

1.     First, internships. There are a few steps Ill have to take to find a position.

  • Five a Day till Payday: Every day, I aim to apply to at least five internships and build and revise my application materials as needed. This involves a comprehensive resume review, an ever-changing cover letter, and joining communities that may open doors to opportunities. In addition, I am pursuing content creation by uploading my daily progress on TikTok @progressofpause.

  • Thirty minutes a day of LeetCode: LeetCode is a platform that hosts traditional Data Structures and Algorithms problems that are used in internship technical interviews. These problems are dry and meticulous, but I must practice them. In addition to my daily practice, Im taking a course at Duke that corresponds to this type of work.

  • Emails to Alumni: For a dedicated amount of time each week, Ill be making direct connections with Duke and Exeter alums searching for informational interviews about software engineering. Im hoping this will give me a better perspective.

2.     Finance. Ill be starting with financial awareness by

  • tracking my daily spending in a Google sheet. Im also developing my investment calendar for this year, aiming to save 8,000 in 2023. Again, Im uniquely positioned to do this at a time in my life without rent, grocery trips, etc.

  • building a 20-year calendar to reach 1,000,000 in investments by 35. This sounds daunting, but I should be on a trajectory if I can make consistent dollar-cost-averaging deposits into relatively secure funds. Of course, again, much of this compound interest depends on the market's health, but since Im a long-term investor, Im changing my perspective from value to simply # of shares.

3.     Blog: 10 minutes a day of writing

  • This is what Im doing right now! I fell off of this project during the fall, and since I didnt take intentional time to devote to writing, I found myself writing only once every month or so. Writing gives me the magnifying glass of my life and opens the doors to daily introspection. Im also spending an hour a week developing snapshots of the months I missed.

4.     Fitness: Weigh-in and Work Out 2x/a wk

  • This one might seem small to the fitness buffs, but I havent worked out consistently since last spring. Ive designated days in the week when I have more flexibility and re-implemented rigidity by scheduling workouts. Im not focused on weight loss but rather on overall strength. Its also a massive plus that working out increases my sleep quality.

5.     Notion: 1 hr/wk of Brainstorm

  • I plan to create a storefront later in the year, but I want to dedicate time to thinking about what tools I use often and how to provide those resources to others.

 

This month, along with being a big month of resolutions, is also when Im undergoing an extensive medical process to freeze my eggs. It sounds about as luxurious as it sounds. Medications shoved in syringes and fridges, timed within far too precise intervals. Im eager to start the process since more haste gives the illusion that the process will be shorter. Im also worried about sharing this process with the outside world, as after I freeze my eggs, I will start hormone replacement therapy. Thats a scary thing to shareI know this is the right decision for my health, but its hard to explain how I know its the right decision. How do you explain to someone that you know youre a man? Its not about liking trucks or being a powerful force but about feeling at home in my own body. Its about feeling like myself. I hope to get to the bottom of this by writing my way through it.

Humankind is bound to face the problem of immortality any year nowwith startup CEOs pledging to donate their brains to computers to build AI networks; we have romanticized the preserved, believing that the intellect we have now will be worth keeping. However, I dont think our brains make us humanI believe we do. We have senses, breaths, and griefall of which, while they incorporate the brain, its difficult for me to fathom as the only factor.

It's tough because I dont believe in an immortal soul, as Socrates claimed, but we have a priori knowledge. So, where does it come from? In my opinion, its immersion. Immersion from parents and caretakers at a young age teaches you there is beauty in imprecisiona stool is a type of chair, and a chair is a type of seat. We understand so much implicitly that its essential to know why we can make sense of the larger picture through small steps of reason.

Writing is more complicated when Im not reading. Im less present and less aware of my perspective of the world when I dont have reading material to make my life feel more extensive. Im trying to keep books in my ears while walking down the path to classIm listening to Homo Deus, which brings the larger scale of what humanity might be up to in the background.

In my Latin class, we read Horaces Odes 1.11, the poem famously known as the carpe diem. It had a far different context than expected. I always interpreted carpe diem as seize the day, an imperative proclamation to ensure that each day is taken without dismissal. While the original poem is similar, there are significant differences, namely that it doesnt quite mean seize the day but pluck the day almost.


I dont believe in trusting the future; this year, Im focusing on trusting each day as its present moment. Im trying to take small things each day, consistently, to build up habits that make the most of each day. Its hard for me to commit a significant amount of time to projects that dont feel pressing, so instead, Im aiming to make the priority just a few pieces every day.

Its hard to build the courage to stab yourself with a needle. I thought being an EMT would shake the nerves out of me, but its an entirely different thing to feel yourself on the other side of the needle, like tickling yourself. Its a feeling that Im getting a little too used to, but before each injection, my hand still hovers over the injection site for at least fifteen seconds. A few deep breaths and a quick look away will do the trick.

Im still petrified of messing something up in this process, possibly hurting a future opportunity to have kids. There are many ways to have kids, through adoption or a surrogate, but at 20 years old, its hard for me to understand or visualize what that future looks like. Kids are expensive, and while Im sure the joy of being a parent is not something I have not fully grasped, its hard for me to envision that especially regarding my financial goals.

The financial goals feel scary in themselves. I dont know exactly what Im saving for since Im still figuring out the next five years, whether for rent in a city Ive never been to or graduate school tuition. Im still figuring out how the puzzle pieces fit together.

So heres to solving it.

Until next, 

Alex

item.title: FEBRUARY: GLOOM
item.content:encoded:
I struggle with failure days. Days that my body gives up on me. I find it hard to have the grace to acknowledge that health comes before work and shake off the oh-so-dreaded guilt.


Today starts a phase of my life I have been waiting for almost six years now. Everything will stay the same; no leaves fall on autumn's first day. It takes you looking up and wishing for them to fall, making the time seem more drastic.

We are bad at waiting. We find ways to fill time rather than watch it pass. Its always easier to be doing, thinking, dreaming, and pursuing than to sit idly and wait.

After my procedure, Ive been dealing with pain management, drinking almost countless bottles of white Gatorade, and sitting curled up holding a heating pad. Being in pain like that makes me angry, which is not a feeling Im used to, but I become frustrated that my body limits what I can push myself to do.

And with that, Ive fallen of the habit of applying every day. Now that Ive stopped for a week, Im trying to figure out how to get back on best. After around 200 applications, I wonder how to use my time best. But right now, Im using that as an excuse to do nothing.

Ive been accepted not to any internship but to a few mentee positions. But the push and pull between software and archaeology are starting to add more stress rather than just an interdisciplinary quirk. 

I must have manifested something in the universe yesterday when I wrote that message. Finally, I got accepted to a program that will compensate me and allow me to work on a larger project, Dukes Code+ program. This is exciting news for someone like me with little experience, but the downside is that it overlaps entirely with the Vulci excavation.

I told Alessandra first. She once again invited me to the Palatine. Im telling myself that this summer is my exploration into software, to build and break projects for at least an hour a day. But I wouldn't say I like to explore it; I must abandon the excavation unless I were to take a gap semester, inevitably pushing back my graduation a semester.

And, of course, now there are logistics to figure out, where to live, how Ill drive, and all sorts of fun adult stuff. Im just grateful the search is over, but Ill still apply to projects within the classics world to ensure I can keep my toe in that oh-so-alluring pond.

On exam day, I am much more aware of my body. Tension in my back, numbness at the bottom of my sinuses, and a few more pimples appear just in time for picture day.

But as exams pass and a moment of lull washes over, I try to keep the urgency I felt, try not to think about what I answered for the last actual false question, and keep that momentum moving.

Now that Ive been accepted into a program, I find it harder to continue pushing my motivation through challenging classes and career decisions.

The exams went well. The projects that everyone else has been able to complete without breaking down? Not so much. I have such a hard time building a program incrementally; I want to rush and implement it all, even to my detriment.

I spent far too many all-nighters for a project that needed to be understood deeply rather than grinding it out hour by hour. But Im now back to the typical state of affairs, outlining papers and ensuring Im not missing any sneaky deadlines.

Reflecting on this time of transition and uncertainty, I am reminded of the importance of being kind to ourselves and taking the time to rest and recharge. In our fast-paced lives, it can be all too easy to become consumed by work or school demands and neglect our physical and mental health. However, by prioritizing self-care, we can ensure that we remain healthy, happy, and fulfilled in our personal and professional lives. So while I am excited to continue pursuing my passions and exploring new opportunities, I am also committed to finding a sustainable balance that allows me to take care of myself and prioritize my well-being.

With that being said, heres to a beautifully gloomy February, filled with moments of rest and reflection and the courage to prioritize self-care even amid uncertainty and transitions. May we all find the strength to be kind to ourselves and prioritize our well-being, and continue to pursue our passions and explore new opportunities with a sense of balance and perspective. Here's to a brighter future, one step at a time.

Until next month,

Alex

item.title: JANUARY: REDISCOVERING
item.content:encoded:
Ive had a hard time keeping a balance this year. Thats not for a lack of joy or enrichmentIve always got a lot going on all at the same time. But as I reevaluate priorities every season, the habit of writing is one that I always find myself coming back to. 

Its New Years resolution season, so Ill reflect on what I set out to achieve:

Goals, 2023

  • Learn Italian proficiently: Ive made steady progress on this goal, but I hope to increase my active engagement by pursuing lessons or taking an online course with an instructor. My proficiency in writing and reading has far surpassed my ability to speak simply due to a lack of practice.

  • Build a habit of reading for both creative and professional endeavors: I have exercised this muscle, but this was a challenging goal to make a SMART goal for meI read more books than last year thanks to my Kindle, but I have a hard time either completing a book or being able to focus my interest on a wide range of genres.

  • Develop a passive income: I realize this goal was a bit disillusioned, as passive income is far more of a myth than is portrayed online. Actively seeking it out as a goal is less effective than chasing the passions that drive those sources of less-active income.

  • Implement a sustainable long-term financial system: I succeeded in this goal far more than I ever expected. I got on a budget this year and received a granularity in my finances, making me not stress about money for the first time. This, along with other adulting things like doing the math to max out my Roth IRA and open a HYSA, has been an incredible foundation to start on, and I cant wait for my older self to pat myself on the back.

  • Get a fulfilling career in Computer Science: Im happy to say that Ill be working at Disney Streaming this summer as a Product Management Intern. Not only am I thrilled to be working at a company like Disney, but more importantly, Im genuinely excited to tackle the challenging problems in Productafter many months of rejection emails and 258 applications, Im grateful that the position that I landed is one that Im excited to contribute to.

  • Get fit: This one has been harder for me. While I thrive on routine, the gym is always the first to fall off and the hardest to start again. I think this year, to continue on this goal, I will allow myself to be more flexible with my scheduleif I miss the 7:00 am wake-up alarm, that shouldnt mean that going to the gym is off the table.

  • Create compelling discography: Ive been writing less prolific songs than in the past. Part of this has been due to the changes in my voicethe progressions that used to feel like muscle memory now feel like a far-fetched stretch, and Im still learning to adapt. And while the volume of my work this year is far less than in the past, Im proud of the quality of the work that I have produced.

Before you think Im another machiavellian maniac, these goals never truly happened in concurrence with one anotherI spent a lot of this year on a heavily irregular sleep schedule, struggling to balance my priorities, and taking courses that I felt largely unqualified for, calling for extra study groups and acts of desperation to understand a sliver of a concept. However, with all that being said, before writing out this list, I felt that I underperformed this year, but I think its hard to make that argument. While I didnt hit all of these goals, I believe I am in a more sustainable place, surrounded by people I care about, and have made substantial progress toward my long-term goals.

Without further ado, lets set some benchmarks that I may or may not be disappointed by this time next year:

Goals, 2024

  • Hit some financial milestones: Now that I have some data, I plan to continue building the muscle of saving early and often. While some of these are lofty goals, even if I dont hit them all at 100%, Ill still be able to thank myself later; but now, I can think about metrics like saving rate, investing a certain amount, or increasing net worth, with varying degrees of control.

  • Build and break projects: After getting my internship, I told myself many of my stressors had fallen by the wayside. My main focuses are school, Pitchforks, and something to be determined. Id like to be proactive about filling that time with fulfilling work, and Ive got many projects I hope to build. I want to develop a Budget Wrapped, flesh out the EdStem Bot idea, and gain more practice with active interrogation with NLP methodologies. 

  • Read 25 books: Im hoping that this goal will be easy with the load of my courses, but Im also pushing myself to find what I love and hate about particular parts of literature versus feeling indifferent or more of a nomad when it comes to genre.

  • Write consistently, for the sake of knowing myself: Another priority that I want to focus on this year is the act of writingits something that I love to do and am grateful that I do, but I never feel too eager to start writing on a blank page. I want to get used to that uncomfortable feeling.

And, as usual, with each of these goals, here are the strategies I plan to use to build these goals into my life.

  • Financial milestones: On a broad scale, I hope to continue saving as much as possible, but I also want to work on the mental side of saving for somethingBen from YNAB talks about the idea that theres no such thing as saving money, but instead we allocate money for a purpose. That money will be spent eventually, just not immediately. I want to work on defining my priorities in my budget to ensure that I can genuinely save for the milestones I want to hit, whether it be investment or travel goals. 

    • The most significant financial obligation Ill have this year is to save for the summerIll be living in Santa Monica, which is more expensive than my life in Durham.

  • Build and break milestones: I aim to flesh out my prototypes for both the Budget Wrapped and the EdStem bot by Spring Break, and I plan to do this by spending at least three hours a week on these projects. This goal seems lofty, but I intend to treat each project as a course and create a pseudo-syllabus.

  • Read 25 books: This one is just mathaim to finish about two books per month. But Id like to do a lot of the heavy lifting of figuring out what to read ahead of time; I never want the but I dont know what book I want to read to override the will to read.

  • Write consistently: I will implement this in my 10-minute-per-day routine; it turns what can seem a daunting habit into a sustainable one, pushing me to write posts like this. I will not pressure my writing but let it be what it is and review my style quarterly to set goals for myself. But for now, lets get some words on the page. 

Ive also spent much of this break with my family, exploring Italy with them and reclaiming the childhood joy of Christmas. But while I stretch to feel those childhood feelings, its only because the world is feeling all the more adult; Ive just found a housing arrangement for working in Santa Monica this summer, which still feels like a fever dream, along with finding our senior year house with three of my best friends. I feel myself on the other side of the halfway point, and its not that I regret anything; instead, I fret over what I might miss in the future. 

I cant make this technically a goal since its hard, or rather, feels superficial, to set benchmarks for this, but I hope to spend more time with friends over this next year. Sometimes, it hits me that Ive only got a year and a half left at Dukea place where Ive had a love-hate relationship but has ultimately seen my most prominent years of growth, many of my what-am-I-doing-with-my-life crises and has brought me to meet mentors who I hope to stay in touch with for as long as I have an itch of intellectual curiosity. 

I havent leaned into the Duke that many people know; I rarely go to any Greek party, I have taken classes with only one other student and the professor, and Ive always preferred having friends all across campus rather than from one pot. However, the Duke that I know, the mornings at Bella Union with Elliot and Rob, stumbling around exploring the Duke Gardens, and staying past when the doors lock in Biddle Music Building, is one that I will surely miss. Its hard to distinguish whether Ill miss that purely because its Duke or because these are my defined college years when Im encouraged to do all the explorations that enrich me. And, of course, its not the physical campus that holds the weight of the sentimental value for me but the people I surround myself with.

As usual, I am starting the year with far more stamina than I know is realistic to anticipate. However, I hope that building a buffer or setting an unrealistic standard helps me see and understand the benefits of hitting the daily benchmarks. My overarching goal is to develop my muscle of saying no, honing in on whats important to me and treating my projects with the same respect I would treat others.

I work in a way that requires the slightest uphill movement; most of that behavior is initiated by Notion databases, a meticulous Google Calendar, and operating on my timeline. I have a strong over-reliance on digital toolssure, I could build a system that acts in place of this Second Brain model, but there always hits a point in the semester where I am reduced to an Expo marker and a whiteboard when the panic truly sets in.

That panic has set in, but its a different tone this timeits not because Im behind in work, but Im planning for the next six months, and there remain many unknowns that Im having trouble accounting for. In these moments of planning and forecasting, a deep, guttural discomfort stems from the unknownI know my capabilities as the captain, and I trust my vessel. Yet, the opacity of the fog makes it difficult to plot my course confidently. Im still learning to embrace this.

The cold has finally hit Durham, almost as karma as I bragged to my parents a week ago that it was warmer here than in Texas. Ive tried to dress to match the occasionusually, when its cold, I throw on a sweatshirt and sweatpants, but that tends to drive me right to the emotional state I aim to avoid, some sense of complacency and intuition that nature is against me, a self-building excuse. Today, I put on a quarter-zip and boots, eager to show professionalism, not to impress anyone, but rather to show myself that theres no reason to sulk back. Ill always prefer rainy to cold weatherI love feeling when the rain hits my skin and watching it sag into the grass. 

As I continue my career in counseling younger students on how to manage my time, I am constantly forced to reckon with holding myself to my wordI know that I likely get more done than the average person, and thats not to be boastful, but instead to claim that this still hasnt hit an internal benchmark. Ive always believed that work fills the space you allocate it; even if you know you could finish a problem in an hour if you have three hours to finish it, and often, even when I lie to myself about having limited time, I still operate subconsciously on a more generous timetable. 

Best,

Alex

item.content:encoded:
It took about three weeks to fall back into the rhythm that Im a little too all familiar with. I kept saying yesa lesson Ive learned a few too many times during this project. 

I think it would be a bit generous to describe myself as stretched-thin at this point, and Im once again reminded that theres a clear distinction between delegation and dependency. 

The tone of my writing so far might lead you to believe that my perspective is pessimisticits quite the opposite: when I sit to work on whatever it may be is up next on my list, Im excited at the chance to show up for myself, and for the project that Im contributing to.

That said, I wanted to show up for myself by writing at least a bit and giving a bit of a life update, even though Ive done a poor job of maintaining this habit. When I stop writing, it makes it all the harder to spend even a few minutes a day putting my thoughts to paperunlike what I remarked last month, this task feels uphill.

Nevertheless, the past few weeks have been hectic, filled with passion projectsnote, not the ones that I had planned to work on in January, but lots of delving headfirst into schoolwork, letting myself sit with a problem in my algorithms class for longer than necessarily needed, but as long as I felt content with it. Ive had a lot of moments of meaningful work this month, but again, an emphasis on a lot.

Until next month,

item.title: MARCH: SETTLE
item.content:encoded:
I have relished working with brutally honest people this monthtypically, thats taken as a bad thing, but I think Ive come to learn that I thrive on direct feedback. 

Im almost tired of writing that I have a lot on my plate, and Im once again kicking myself for the goals I set at the beginning of this semester. I will say that this month, Ive done a much better job of keeping track of all the monkeys in my circus, but Im still struggling with saying no, as always.

Ive had a lot of fun looking forward to this summer, planning out all of the logistics, but I am filled with a sense of dread when thinking about moving all of my stuff out and out of a dorm for the final time. This is my seventh year of living in a dorm, and I think its an understatement to say that Im ready to graduate from this stage of life. Im looking forward to my kitchen and building a space that is not just for storage but for settling.

I hit a significant financial milestone, this goal that should, theoretically, compel me to slow my pace regarding the rat race of income. Of course, the only problem is that Ive built that habit almost to the point that it's ingrained in my psyche. The problem with financial goals is that the goalpost always moves. When it comes to academics, you aim for an A. My career is a little more flexibleI strive to work with genuinely curious people in a challenging environment. However, with personal finance, I could aim to hit $X in net worth or X months in savings, but once that milestone is hit, I am immediately looking at the next goal post.

I will say that building these automated financial structures in my life has made me better at not just organizing a calendar but also my life prioritiesgifts for my sister and moms birthday, being proactive about opportunities, and building projects that Im passionate about. That includes developing a House Course on Full-Stack Development, a skill Ive acquired over the past year. Im excited to work with students in a different way than I typically do as a tutor or a TA, but instead, focusing my energy on building their passion for their projects.

Ive made a more intentional effort to reach out to friends from years ago, narrowing the scope of where I hope to live on the East Coast. I like the idea of hopping on a plane and going to Boston or New York, even if I dont necessarily see my life there. Im stuck in limbo between wanting a fast-paced life and being able to truly clock out of my busyness by immersing myself. 

I turned 22 this month and spent some time with my partner and some friends, debriefing life and our respective woes. I used to be a huge its my birthday guy, but this year, even my boss reminded me that I had to celebrate.

With that, Im off to celebrate my wins this month and look forward to the final 20-something days of the semester before heading off to California and moving out of a dorm for the last time.

Best,

Alex
